instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD1: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD1? PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 is a power rail that powers the soldered on SSDs.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
hi,

There was fluid in the CB722 area CB722 was removed and the area was cleaned. it draws 0.05 amps right now and the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is a bit hot. I couldn't find the part code of the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>


f7000 = 12.68 voltage
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>= 20 Voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is the T2 chip.

Is the machine detected in DFU mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
1- The battery is full sign does not appear on the screen, while the battery is plugged in, the current drawn decreases to 0.30, 0.60, 0.77, 0.85 and 0.05 amps, and the same thing is repeated all the time. I'm noticing the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is getting a little hot. Is it normal for the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> to get hot at 0.05 amps? This device is in contact with liquid. 
2-I haven't tried DFU mode because there is no battery charging message on the screen and it won't charge.

3-cb721 is not in place, does it prevent it from opening?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
You should solder CB721 at the end, but doesn't prevent the board to boot.

If all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present, machine should enter DFU; if T2 is good.
To complete DFU, SSD voltages must be there too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7909</CAPACITOR> = 1.8 Volt
<CAPACITOR>C7903</CAPACITOR> = 1.0 Volt
<RESISTOR>R8601</RESISTOR> = 1.8  Volt
<CAPACITOR>C8648</CAPACITOR> = 2.5 Volt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message: I'm not sure if you tried DFU, or not yet...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message: The device does not draw a constant current. In the continuous restart mode, the current rises to 0.85 and then drops to 0.05. Doesn't that indicate that the device is not turned on? In the video, it is seen that there is a battery sign, no battery sign is displayed on the screen. I tried DFU mode and it did not work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://disk.yandex.com.tr/i/P4_oYonTLcqaRQ[/URL]

current drops to 0 continuously

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not stable?
AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages try to appear at least?

Try to understand, many times DFU fix boards not turning on.
T2 must turn on the board, when works properly.
Fixing T2 corrupted firmware, doesn't require the board to turn on; just need above mentioned voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  CC764 = 11.11 Voltage and 12.34 Voltage not stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> stable voltage (L6960/91)?
Also check if AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present, or pulse at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
[U]L6960/61)[/U] = 3.3 Volt fixed
91 ? 61

Where else should I read the SLPS2R voltage?

<CAPACITOR>C7909</CAPACITOR> = 1.8 Volt  <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
<CAPACITOR>C7903</CAPACITOR> = 1.0 Volt <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
<RESISTOR>R8601</RESISTOR> = 1.8 Volt <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD1</SIGNAL>
<CAPACITOR>C8648</CAPACITOR> = 2.5 Volt  <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
Sorry, I meant L6960/61.
A lot of AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages on pages 75/76.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
[U]L7811 [/U]- <SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> = 0.8 Voltage After 30 seconds, it drops to 0 voltage and returns to the same voltage. 
[U]L7813[/U]-  <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>    = 1.8  Voltage After 30 seconds, it drops to 0 voltage and returns to the same voltage. 
[U]L7814[/U]-  <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>    = 1.1  Voltage After 30 seconds, it drops to 0 voltage and returns to the same voltage. 
[U]L7816[/U]- <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL>    = 0.9  Voltage After 30 seconds, it drops to 0 voltage and returns to the same voltage. 

In the video I sent you, the current was falling to 0, at that moment all voltages go out and then it comes back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
Is <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltage stable?
Even 5V there (but stable) is enough for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to generate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
You may need to resolder, or change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

BTW, check without battery connected, only charger plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
current draw only when the charger is plugged in 0.06 amps

Motherboard is on blank board only charger is plugged in.
all voltages are stable without battery <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> stable 20 volts

L7811,L7813,L7814,L7816 voltages are stable with no battery installed

(no battery) <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> pin 5 voltage is not stable 12.24 volts then drops to 0 volts . is this normal ?

F7000/1 12.24 Volt stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
So you get stable SSD and SLPS2R voltages (no battery).
Check if AWAKE voltages are stable too.
If yes, then machine must appear in DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message: Check if AWAKE voltages ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
Where can I check the awake voltage?

Where can I check the awake voltage, by the way, RB305 is corroded and broken, I changed it, but the situation is the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message: Take a look at page 75 & 76...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
The device draws 0.22 amps at the first voltage, then drops to 0.05 amps. After about 1 minute, it drops to 0.0 amps and then returns to 0.05.

as if the device will turn on but there is a short circuit, so it won't turn on

<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 0.7 voltage
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE = 0.8 Voltage
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.1 Voltage
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> =3.3 Voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A LIQUID CONTACT
threads.message:
As you've found broken RB305, there may be other resistor corroded in other areas.
If all above mentioned voltages are stabke, machine must go into DFU.

If not, T2 has internal problem, or is affected by accumulated crap underneath.
Try again, and be sure to exactly follow all the steps from DFU tutorial.

threads.message: As I said before, the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> gets a little hot, I don't think it's normal. The current drawn by the device is at 0.05 and the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is a little warm
